entry.title: Japan 2009/4
entry.summary:
Shooting Lemma on an Angle Equality

Let \(\Gamma\) be the circumcircle of triangle \(ABC\). A circle with center \(O\) is tangent to side \(BC\) at point \(P\) and tangent to the arc \(BC\) of \(\Gamma\) not containing \(A\) at point \(Q\). Prove that if \(\angle{BAO} = \angle{CAO}\), then \(\angle{PAO} = \angle{QAO}\).

Solution

Let \(M\) be the midpoint of arc \(BC\) containing \(A\), \(N \neq A\) be the intersection of line \(AO\) with \(\Gamma\), \(O_{\Gamma}\) be the center of \(\Gamma\), and \(\omega\) be the circle with center \(O\) described in the problem statement.

\(M\), \(P\), and \(Q\) are then collinear by the so called \(\textit{shooting lemma}\), which we prove as follows. It is clear that there exists a homothety mapping \(\omega\) to \(\Gamma\), since \(O_\Gamma\), \(O\), and \(Q\) are collinear, \(MO_{\Gamma} \) is parallel to \(PO\) (both perpendicular to \(\overline{BC})\), and both \(\triangle{MO_{\Gamma}Q}\) and \(\triangle{POQ}\) are isosceles. Consequently, \(M\), \(P\), and \(Q\) are collinear.

We now claim that \(M\), \(O_{\Gamma}\), \(N\) are also collinear. We have \[ \measuredangle CBN = \measuredangle CAN = \measuredangle CAO = \measuredangle OAB = \measuredangle NAB = \measuredangle NCB, \] so \(N\) must be the midpoint of arc \(\widehat{BC}\) not containing \(A\). Thus, \(MN\) is simply the diameter of \(\Gamma\).

We now use the above to show that \(A\), \(P\), \(O\), \(Q\) are concyclic. Using the homothety defined above, we see that \[ \measuredangle OPQ = \measuredangle O_{\Gamma}MQ = \measuredangle NMQ = \measuredangle NAQ = \measuredangle OAQ, \] so \(A\), \(P\), \(O\), \(Q\) are concyclic.

Lastly, since \(\triangle{OPQ}\) is isosceles, \[ \measuredangle QAO = \measuredangle QPO = \measuredangle OQP = \measuredangle OAP. \]

\(\blacksquare\)

Motivation

Once the configuration for the shooting lemma is found, the key observation is that \(A\), \(P\), \(O\), and \(Q\) are concyclic. This requires discovering point \(N\) along the way, which is both the antipode of \(M\) and the intersection of \(AO\) with \(\Gamma\).

entry.title: Japan 2010/2
entry.summary:
Powers of 2 Divide \(n^n - m\)

Let \(k\) and \(m\) be positive integers such that \(m\) is odd. Prove that there exists some positive integer \(n\) such that \(n^n - m\) is divisible by \(2^k\).

Solution

We prove the claim by induction on \(k\). For the base case when \(k=1\), any odd \(n\) will suffice. Now suppose that for some \(k\), there exists \(n=N\) such that \(2^k\mid n^n-m = N^N-m\) for each odd \(m\). Note that \(N\) must be odd. We then show that there exists some \(n\) such that \(2^{k+1}\mid n^n-m\) for each odd \(m\).

If \(2^{k+1}\mid N^N-m\), we are done by letting \(n=N\). On the other hand, suppose \(2^{k+1}\nmid N^N-m\). By assumption, \(2^k\mid N^N-m\) so let \(N^N-m=2^k\cdot t\) for odd positive integer \(t\).

We claim that \(2^{k+1}\) divides \[\left(2^k + N\right)^{\left(2^k + N\right)} - m.\]

Indeed since both \(N\) and \(t\) are odd,

\[\begin{align*} \left(2^k + N\right)^{\left(2^k + N\right)} - m &\equiv \left(2^k + N\right)^N - m\pmod{2^{k+1}}\\ &\equiv N^N + \tbinom{N}{1}N^{N-1}\cdot 2^k - m \pmod{2^{k+1}}\\ &= 2^k\left(t + N^N\right) \\ &\equiv 0 \pmod{2^{k+1}}, \end{align*}\]

as desired.

\(\blacksquare\)

Motivation

The motivation for the solution is to analyze the quantity \(n^n\) modulo \(2^k\) for each positive integer \(k\) and odd \(n\).

For \(k=1\), odd \(n^n\) yields \(1\), \(3\) \(\pmod{4}\).

For \(k=2\), odd \(n^n\) yields \(1\), \(3\), \(5\), \(7\) \(\pmod{8}\).

For \(k=3\), odd \(n^n\) yields \(1\), \(11\), \(5\), \(7\), \(9\), \(3\), \(13\), \(15\) \(\pmod{16}\).

For \(k=4\), odd \(n^n\) yields \(1\), \(27\), \(21\), \(23\), \(9\), \(19\), \(29\), \(15\), \(17\), \(11\), \(5\), \(7\), \(25\), \(3\), \(13\), \(31\) \(\pmod{32}\).

To reach the solution above, it suffices to notice that for each term in the \(k=k_0\) sequence, we either add \(2^{k_0}\) or leave it be to reach the \(k=k_0+1\) sequence (looping through the \(k=k_0\) sequence once).

Interestingly, the problem statement is also equivalent to saying that these quantities are unique modulo \(2^k\) (ie. there does not exist \(n_0\) and \(n_1\) such that \(n_0^{n_0} \equiv n_1^{n_1}\).)

With that mindset, one of the difficulties was in avoiding a certain anti-pattern/red herring. For each \(k\) from \(1\) to \(4\), we mysteriously find that if \(n_0^{n_0} \equiv n_1 \pmod{2^k}\), then \(n_1^{n_1} \equiv n_0 \pmod{2^k} \).

When I was solving the problem, I ended up trying to prove this anti-pattern, which actually stops at \(k=5\). For example, \(5^5 \equiv 53 \pmod{64}\) but \(53^{53} \equiv 37 \not\equiv 5 \pmod{64}\).

entry.title: Japan 2010/1
entry.summary:
The Foot is the Circumcenter

Given an acute-angled triangle \(ABC\) such that \(AB \neq AC\), let \(H\) be the foot of the altitude from \(A\) to \(BC\). The points \(P\) and \(Q\) are defined in such a way that if the three points \(A\), \(B\), \(P\) and the three points \(A\), \(C\), \(Q\) are collinear in this order respectively, then the four points \(B\), \(C\), \(P\), \(Q\) are concyclic and \(HP = HQ\). Prove that \(H\) is the circumcenter of triangle \(APQ\).

Solution

Let \(O\) be the circumcenter of \((APQ)\) and \(H'\) be the foot of the altitude from \(A\) to side \(PQ\). We show that \(H = O\).

First, observe that \(\triangle{APQ}\) is similar to \(\triangle{ACB}\) since \(\measuredangle PAQ = - \measuredangle CAB\) and \(\measuredangle APQ = \measuredangle BPQ = \measuredangle BCQ = -\measuredangle ACB\). Consequently, \(\measuredangle PAH' = \measuredangle CAH\), so \(AH'\) is the isogonal of \(AH\) (and vice versa) with respect to \(\triangle{APQ}\).

Next, we show that \(O\) lies on \(AH\). Since the orthocenter of \(\triangle{APQ}\) lies on \(AH'\), and \(AH\) is the isogonal of \(AH'\), the result follows. In other words, \[ \measuredangle QAO = 90^\circ - \measuredangle APQ = \measuredangle PAH' = \measuredangle CAH.\]

Finally, it is well known that \(O\) lies on the perpendicular bisectors of \(\triangle{APQ}\). In particular, consider the perpendicular bisector of side \(PQ\), say \(\ell\). \(O\) must be the intersection of \(AH\) and \(\ell\). Since \(HP = HQ\), \(H\) is preceisely that intersection. Hence, \(O = AH\cap\ell = H\) as desired.

\(\blacksquare\)

Motivation

The notorious fact that the orthocenter and the circumcenter are isogonal conjugates appears. This problem is a prototypical example of its application.

entry.title: Japan 2010/4
entry.summary:
A Cyclic Fractional Inequality

Let \(x\), \(y\), \(z\) be positive real numbers. Prove that \[ \frac {1 + yz + zx}{(1 + x + y)^2} + \frac {1 + zx + xy}{(1 + y + z)^2} + \frac {1 + xy + yz}{(1 + z + x)^2}\geq 1.\]

Solution

Each term on the left-hand side of the inequality is cyclic, so WLOG we show that \[\frac{1+zx+xy}{(1+y+z)^2} \geq \frac{x}{x+y+z}.\] We have \[\begin{align*} &\quad (x-1)^2 \geq 0 \\ \iff&\quad (x^2 + 1)(y + z) \geq 2x(y + z) \\ \iff&\quad (1+zx+xy)(x+y+z) \geq x(1+y+z)^2 \\ \iff&\quad \frac{1+zx+xy}{(1+y+z)^2} \geq \frac{x}{x+y+z}, \end{align*}\] so \[\sum_{cyc}\frac{1+zx+xy}{(1+y+z)^2} \geq \sum_{cyc}\frac{x}{x+y+z} = 1.\]

\(\blacksquare\)

Motivation

This inequality is homogenized, but manipulating it seems like a huge ordeal. For example, if we think of adding the terms, we end up with some ugly 6th degree polynomial on the numerator of the left-hand side. So this suggests to us that dealing with each term individually is the way to go. One thing we can try is bounding each individual term against some value. If the sum of these bounds evaluates to some value greater than or equal to 1, we would be done.

Now to think up such value, we can think about what we don't want. We probably don't want constants because it's likely that we would be able to adjust \(x\), \(y\), \(z\) in such a way that allows that inequality to break. This means that we'll have to have some combination of \(x\), \(y\), \(z\) in the bound. Another fact that may help is that the terms in the left-hand side of the inequality are cyclic, suggesting that the bounds are probably going to be cyclic.

Going through this train of thought, we may eventually find the following bounds:

\[\begin{align*} \frac{1+xy+xz}{(1+y+z)^2} \geq \frac{x^k}{x^k + y^k + z^k}, \\ \frac{1+yz+yx}{(1+z+x)^2} \geq \frac{y^k}{x^k + y^k + z^k}, \\ \frac{1+zx+zy}{(1+x+y)^2} \geq \frac{z^k}{x^k + y^k + z^k}, \end{align*}\]

where \(k\) is any real value. Now to determine \(k\), WLOG, note that \[(1+xy+xz) (x^k + y^k + z^k) \geq x^k(1+y+z)^2\] must be true. This looks like weighted AM-GM, so consider the following fact.

Whenever we have \[a_{1}^{w_1}a_{2}^{w_2}\cdots a_{n}^{w_n} \leq w_1a_1 + w_2a_2 + \cdots + w_na_n,\] the product of the exponent and the coefficient on each variable equate on either sides.

Therefore, we want the exact same thing to happen in our current situation. Expanding and simplifying our inequality, we get

\[\begin{align*} &x^{k+1}y + x^{k+1}z + y^k+xy^{k+1} + xy^kz + z^k + xyz^k + xz^{k+1} \\ \geq\ &x^ky^2 + z^2x^k + 2x^kzy + 2x^kz+ 2x^ky. \end{align*}\]

So using the trick on \(x\), we want \[\begin{align*} &(k+1)\cdot 1 + (k+1)\cdot 1 + 1\cdot 1 +1\cdot 1 + 1\cdot 1 + 1\cdot 1 \\ =\ &k\cdot 1 + k\cdot 1 + k\cdot 2 + k\cdot 2 + k\cdot 2. \end{align*}\]

Solving for \(k\), we get \(k=1\).

Letting \(k=1\) in our inequality and simplifying, we get \[x^2y + x^2z + y + z \geq 2xz + 2xy.\]

This is equivalent to \((x^2 + 1)(y + z) \geq 2x(y + z)\), which is the same as \(x^2 + 1 \geq 2x,\) or \((x-1)^2 \geq 0\). To summarize, we have shown that

\[\begin{align*} \frac{1+xy+xz}{(1+y+z)^2} \geq \frac{x}{x + y +z}, \\ \frac{1+yz+yx}{(1+z+x)^2} \geq \frac{y}{x + y + z}, \\ \frac{1+zx+zy}{(1+x+y)^2} \geq \frac{z}{x + y + z}, \end{align*}\]

so adding gives us the result. Also, note that although we have used AM-GM as a motivator for finding the value of \(k\), it will not actually appear in a formal write-up of the solution.
